choices.text: The membranous urethra lies just distal to the verumontanum
Bulbar urethra is located where the urethra penetrates the pelvic floor and it is the usual site of urethral rupture at the time of a pelvic fracture
The bulbar urethra extends from the membranous urethra to the penoscrotal junction
The urethral lining changes from transitional cell epithelium proximally to stratified squamous cell epithelium distally

questions.text: Which statement is not correct regarding male urethra?
questions.solution:
Membranous urethra is located where the urethra penetrates the pelvic floor and it is the usual site of rupture at time of pelvic fracture. All other statements are correct.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1538.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the given voiding urethrogram?
questions.solution:
• A voiding cystogram showing a dilated bladder with a dilated prostatic urethra above an obstruction at the level of the posterior urethral valve

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1538.

questions.text: Which is not a part of the treatment strategy for posterior urethral valve?
questions.solution:
Ducket's repair is done for hypospadias correction

Rest all are treatment options for posterior urethral valve.


DUCKETT'S REPAIR

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1539.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of a surgery for hypospadias?
questions.solution:
• Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.
  • Surgery is indicated to improve sexual function, to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons
  • Gonadoblastoma is seen in individuals with mixed gonadal dysgenesis (risk 15-25%), which is associated with cryptorchidism, hypospadias, gynaecomastia or female internal genitalia. It seldom occurs in phenotypical and genotypical males.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 86, The testis and scrotum, Pg: 1571

questions.text: A young male patient had urethral injury after road traffic accident. Following procedure has been performed. What is the likely procedure?
questions.solution:
(a)Percutaneous puncture of the bladder with passage of a guidewire into the bladder followed by dilatation of the track over the guidewire.

(b)Thereby allowing placement of a catheter into the bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The urinary bladder, Pg: 1509.

choices.text: High riding prostate on digital rectal examination

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of acute urethral injury?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and a high riding prostate on digital rectal examination.
  • There is typically marked bruising of the pubic area, scrotum and penis.
  • If the diagnosis is suspected, a urethrogram performed with water-soluble contrast media is confirmatory

Urinary incontinence.

Incontinence is rare. In complex cases, the injury may affect the prostate-membranous urethra with a bladder neck tear. These patients have a higher risk of incontinence.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1542.

choices.text: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as practicable using the Seldinger technique
The conventional management of such an injury is delayed surgical reconstruction
Excision of the scar tissue and end-to-end anastomosis

questions.text: Which is not a part of standard urethral disruption injury management protocol?
questions.solution:
• A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as practicable using the Seldinger technique.
  • The distended bladder may be palpable, making suprapubic catheterisation straight-forward, but often the bruising and swelling associated with the fracture makes this difficult and ultrasound guidance is required.
  • The two ends of the urethra, having been torn apart, become separated by a haematoma.
  • With time, this haematoma resolves and is replaced by fibrosis.
  • This pelvic fracture urethral disruption injury is technically not a stricture of the urethra but is often, erroneously, described as being one.
  • The conventional management of such an injury is delayed surgical reconstruction with excision of the scar tissue and end-to-end anastomosis.
  • This surgery should be delayed until the patient has recovered from any other injuries and is usually undertaken 3-6 months later.
  • It is a highly challenging technical procedure and should be undertaken only in specialist centres.
  • Some surgeons continue to undertake early attempts to realign the urethral ends endoscopically, and while there are some successful reports, most experts feel that there is an increased risk of sepsis, true stricture, incontinence and erectile dysfunction (ED).

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83 The urinary bladder, Pg : 1509.

questions.text: Most common site for urethral stricture?
questions.solution:
• Post Inflammatory strictures are less common since the introduction of effective antibiotic treatment of gonorrhoea.
  • The stricture is most commonly seen in the bulbar urethra but submeatal strictures also occur.
  • There is infection in the periurethral glands, which persists after inadequately treated gonorrhoea.
  • The infection spreads to cause a periurethritis, which heals by fibrosis.
  • Most strictures appear within 1 year of infection but may not cause difficulty in micturition for some time later.

The common causes of urethral stricture are:

  • lichen sclerosus (LS);
  • iatrogenic (post catheter and/or instrumentation);
  • sexually transmitted diseases (gonorrhoea);
  • post radiation;
  • traumatic;
  • idiopathic;
  • congenital.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1542.

questions.text: A 28 years old male patient presents with voiding LUTS. On out patient clinic uroflowmetry is done which is as follows. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Urinary flow rate trace from a patient with a urethral stricture.
  • Note the prolonged flow with the typical plateau shape of the curve

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1543.

choices.text: Often associated with polycystic ovaries and causes urinary retention
There is some evidence that sacral neuromodulation can be effective

questions.text: Which is not true regarding Fowler's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• This idiopathic condition, which was described by Fowler and Kirby, is associated with an abnormal myotonic discharge in the striated urethral sphincter that can be detected by sphincter electromyography.
  • It is often associated with polycystic ovaries and causes urinary retention in women and should not be confused with a urethral stricture.
  • Urethral dilatation is ineffective and the retention is best treated by intermittent self-catheterisation.
  • There is some evidence that sacral neuromodulation can be effective

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 27th Edition, Chapter 79, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1485.

choices.text: An inability to retract the foreskin for intercourse

questions.text: Indications for circumcision are all, except?
questions.solution:
• In infants and young boys, circumcision is most usually performed at the request of the parents for social or religious reasons.
  • Medical indications for circumcision in boys include true phimosis, BXO (rare under the age of 5 years), recurrent attacks of balanoposthitis and recurrent urinary tract infections with an abnormal upper urinary tract.
  • In adults, circumcision is indicated because of an inability to retract the foreskin for intercourse, for splitting of an abnormally tight frenulum or for recurrent balanitis

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 20 Pediatric Urology, Pg: 279.

choices.text: The Plastibell device can be used in infants
Most commonly performed for traumatic reasons
Indicated when there is true phimosis
Never use monopolar diathermy when performing circumcision

questions.text: Not true regarding circumcision?
questions.solution:
Circumcision, being the removal of the foreskin, is the oldest and most common surgical procedure and is usually performed for cultural reasons. About 40% of males worldwide are circumcised. Circumcision is performed in Judaism, on day 8 of life (brit milah), and in Islam (khitan), at varying ages. In early infancy, circumcision can be performed under local anaesthesia using simple devices like the PlastiBell or Gomco clamp. In older boys under general anaesthesia, the foreskin is removed with a blade or scissors, followed by attention to haemostasis and skin apposition with sutures or glue. Complications include bleeding, dehiscence, infection, cicatrix, adhesion formation, meatal stenosis, the removal of too little or too much tissue, cosmetic concerns and rarely urethral injury or amputation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 20 Pediatric Urology, Pg: 279.

questions.text: The most common treatment given for erectile dysfunction is?
questions.solution:
• Treatment for most patients involves the use of the phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (such as sildenafil) with intracavernosal injection of alprostadil, vacuum erection devices and penile implants reserved for resistant cases.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1530.

questions.text: Management of acute phase of Peyronie's disease?
questions.solution:
• While the aetiology is uncertain, there is an association with Dupuytren's contracture.
  • The natural history of the condition is that it typically progresses for 18-24 months before stabilising.
  • During this acute (or active) phase of the disease, surgery is not indicated, and a variety of medical treatments have been tried, although none with any good evidence of benefit.
  • When the disease has stabilised (the chronic or stable phase), the crucial issue is whether the patient is still able to have sexual intercourse.
  • If he can, then no treatment is indicated, while if the deformity prevents penetration, or makes it difficult, then corrective treatment is indicated.
  • Using this criterion, only around a quarter of men require treatment.
  • While injections of collagenase have been recently licensed for this condition, the commonest treatment is surgery with the Nesbitt procedure being the most common procedure.
  • This operation corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis, albeit with some accompanying loss of length,

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1550

choices.text: The commoner and is due to venous congestion
The penis remains erect and remains painless
Blood taken from the penis shows hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis

questions.text: Which is not true regarding ischaemic priapism?
questions.solution:
lschaemic priapism lschaemic or veno-occlusive priapism is the more common. It is due to venous congestion, with consequent thrombosis and ischaemia. The penis remains erect and becomes painful. This is a pathological erection and the glans penis and corpus spongiosum are not involved. The condition is most commonly seen as a side effect of medication, most notably antipsychotic medication and intracavernosal injections. It can also arise as a complication of hypercoagulable blood disorders such as sickle cell disease or leukaemia. A small proportion of cases are caused by malignant disease in the corpora cavernosa or the pelvis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1551.

choices.text: Consequence of traumatic damage to the central penile artery, usually as a consequence of blunt perineal trauma
Blood gas analysis shows the characteristics of venous blood

questions.text: Not true regarding non ischaemic priapism?
questions.solution:
• This rarer form of priapism arises as a consequence of traumatic damage to the central penile artery, usually as a consequence of blunt perineal trauma.
  • A fistula develops between the artery and the sinusoidal space, which results in a persistent erection that is painless, in contrast to the ischaemic priapism.
  • Blood gas analysis shows the characteristics of arterial blood and Doppler scanning and selective arteriography will demonstrate the fistula.
  • Treatment is not an emergency, since there is no ischaemia, and is most appropriately achieved by selective arterial embolisation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1551.

questions.text: Aetiology of penile cancer are all except?
questions.solution:
• Circumcision soon after birth confers immunity against carcinoma of the penis.
  • Later circumcision does not seem to have the same benefit, with the assumption that smegma is in some way carcinogenic.
  • Human papillomavirus infection (HPV types 16 and 18) is a risk factor, as are BXO and smoking.
  • Phimosis and chronic balanoposthitis are known to be contributory factors, and there are definite pre carcinomatous states including leukoplakia of the glans, which is similar to the condition seen on the tongue, and penile intraepithelial neoplasia (PeIN)

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1551.

choices.text: PeIN is typically seen as a red cutaneous patch on the penis
When it occurs on the glans penis, it is known as Bowen's disease
Treatment is by means of topical 5-FU cream
CO2 laser ablation or surgical excision can be done

questions.text: Not true regarding penile intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.solution:
• PeIN is typically seen as a red cutaneous patch on the penis (Figure).
  • When it occurs on the glans penis, it is known as erythroplasia of Queyrat and when it occurs on the shaft of the penis it is called Bowen's disease.
  • There are several other benign causes of red patches on the penis, and when there is clinical doubt as to the underlying diagnosis a biopsy is indicated.
  • When the diagnosis of carcinoma in situ is confirmed, treatment is by means of topical 5-FU cream, CO2 laser ablation or surgical excision.

PENILE EPITHELIAL NEOPLASIA

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1552.

choices.text: NSU can affect both men and women
NSU is a STI that is the commonest cause of urethritis
In around 40% of cases it is due to Gonorrhea
The standard treatment regimes are azithromycin as a single dose or doxycycline orally for 7 days

questions.text: All are true regarding non-specific urethritis, except?
questions.solution:
• NSU is a STI that is the commonest cause of urethritis in the Western world.
  • In around 40% of cases it is due to Chlamydia trachomatis with other cases being caused by ureaplasma urealyticum, Trichomonas vaginalisor Mycoplasma genitalium.
  • The causative agent in up to 50% of cases is unknown.
  • NSU can affect both men and women and asymptomatic infection is common in both.
  • In men, dysuria and a white mucopurulent urethral discharge appear up to 6 weeks after sexual intercourse.
  • Dysuria is usual.
  • The urine appears to be clear but may contain 'threads' or pus cells.
  • Epididymitis is common and urethral stricture is a potential late complication.
  • In women, the condition is usually asymptomatic, although it can present as vaginal discharge or as a form of urethrotrigonitis.
  • It may result in cervicitis or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • Exclusion of gonorrheal infection is important.
  • The standard treatment regimes are azithromycin as a single dose or doxycycline orally for 7 days.
  • Treatment is usually effective, although relapse is common, especially in men, in whom the prostate may act as a reservoir of infection

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Urethra and Penis, Pg: 1554.

questions.text: All can be used for treatment for Ta lesion over glans penis, except?
questions.solution:
TA LESION ON GLANS PENIS

Reference: Campbell-Walsh-Wein Urology 12th Edition, Pg: 1753.

choices.text: Patient is kept on follow up, when nodes become palpable
No lymph node dissection for him

questions.text: An elderly patient with Ca Penis underwent partial penile amputation. Biopsy report came as a T2 lesion. What will be the appropriate timing for lymph node management (clinically N0 nodes)?
questions.solution:
Here the primary lesion is T2 hence lymph node dissection becomes mandatory even if it is clinically N0. The best results are from immediate adjuvant lymph node dissection (5 year survival 83%) and the worst results are from surveillance and delayed lymphadenectomy (5 year survival 36%).

  • Several studies have analyzed the survival of men undergoing early versus delayed lymphadenectomy according to pathologic evaluation of nodal status
  • The best results were from immediate adjunctive lymph node dissection (83%), with the next best from immediate therapeutic lymphadenectomy (66%).
  • The worst results were from the surveillance and delayed lymphadenectomy group (36%), in whom dissection was delayed until palpable nodes developed.

Reference: Campbell-Walsh-Wein Urology 12th Edition, Pg: 1757.

choices.text: Right side, surveillance for left side

questions.text: Suppose the above mentioned patient has clinically N1 nodes on right groin, which side would you operate on?
questions.solution:
Inguinal lymph node dissection should always be bilateral even if the patient has unilateral adenopathy on presentation.

Reference: Campbell-Walsh-Wein Urology 12th Edition, Pg: 1764.
